Award.AwardTitle: DMREF/Collaborative Research: Synthesis of Colloidal Crystals Guided by Particle-Based Theory and Simulation

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Designing Materials to Revolutionize and Engineer our Future (DMREF) collaborative research project will use a combination of theory, numerical simulation, and experiment to discover and synthesize new crystalline materials that can enable the manufacturing of metamaterials. Metamaterials have unique periodic structures that can be used to manipulate electromagnetic or mechanical energy. The materials will be formed from the self-assembly of colloidal particles in suspension. This route to metamaterials is especially flexible, because many kinds of interactions among the particles can be exploited to form new crystalline materials. In addition, it allows better control over the formation process, which can reduce defects in the resulting crystalline structures. The results of the project will provide scientists and engineers with improved tools for identifying colloidal systems of interest, predicting stable crystalline structures, and guiding synthesis of the new materials.

Theory, simulation, and experiments will be integrated into a program to design systems of colloidal particles that assembly into desired crystalline structures. New theoretical and simulation methods will be developed to predict stable and metastable crystal structures in colloidal systems, with a focus on enhancing capabilities of classical density functional theory and applying hyper-parallel tempering simulation methods. Experimental tools for measuring and designing colloidal potentials and analyzing crystal structures will be extended to binary mixtures. The focus will be on developing and measuring suitable potentials for binary systems through the use of different particle sizes and materials, doublets/dumbbells, and Janus configurations, and on characterizing crystal structures using advanced confocal microscopy techniques. The results will be used to design colloidal systems that assemble into desired crystalline structures. Three specific platforms to be considered are solid-fluid and solid-solid polymorphic transitions in binary mixtures of spherical particles of different size and interaction potential, plastic to close-packed solid transitions for doublet/dumbbell particles, and the formation of non-close-packed structures for particles with orientation-dependent attraction (Janus).

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was concerned with the developing the science and engineering of ordered materials created by the assembly of colloidal particles. This is an important avenue in the creation of new materials with controlled structures at microscopic length scales, an important component of the Materials Genome Initiative. There are two integrated components of the research program. First, the development and application of assembly and characterization techniques for new materials, exploiting controlled interactions of the colloidal particles with each other and with substrates. This work is carried out by the group of Michael Bevan at Johns Hopkins University. Second, developing and applying molecular modeling techniques from statistical mechanics to calculate the properties of these novel materials and to predict new structures. This work is carried out by the group of David Ford and Peter Monson at the University of Massachusetts.

The intellectual meritof the research was based on the broad fundamental insights into colloidal assembly processes through the development of new modeling tools, extending such tools to increasingly complex particle shapes, and guiding the design of real-world experimental systems. The broader impacts associated with this project included the discovery, development, and optimization of tools to enable advanced material manufacturing as well as training undergraduate and graduate students through participation in the project.

The outcomes of this research, disseminated in presentations and journal articles, include, on the experimental side, a better understanding of how external fields mediate anisotropic colloidal interactions and their assembly into non-trivial microstructures and, one the modeling side, discovery of a new metastable phase of hard spheres, new results on two-component self-assembly and molecular simulation techniques for studying the effects of changing model parameters upon self-assembly. Findings include: (1) developing models of how single anisotropic particles interact with surfaces and external fields to control their position and orientation in assembly processes, (2) validating in experiments how different electric and magnetic field configurations indeed control interactions of single particles with surfaces, external fields, and other particles, (3) the development of new methods to extract complete information about interactions from microscopy movies to better understand how to control field mediated colloidal assembly, (4) discovery of a metastable phase of hard spheres with a 16-particle unit cell, (5) effect of adding an additional component upon assembly of patchy particles on a surface, and (6) modeling parameters such as particle size and anisotropy can be used as sampling variables in molecular simulations of colloidal assembly.
